# Draft:Doian culture

The Doian culture was a prehistoric Stone Age archaeological culture primarily associated with the inter-riverine region of southern Somalia,  around the Jubba and Shabelle river valleys. The culture is best documented at archeological site of  Buur Heybe, particular Gogoshiis Qabe rock shelter, where excavations have revealed a stratified sequence ranging from the Middle Stone Age (MSA) to the Later Stone Age (LSA). The Eibian/Doian toolkit—first identified by Paolo Graziosi in 1935 was found in distinctive gravel layers and includes microlithic tools such as small points, scrapers, trihedral rods, and pressure-flaked implements made of exotic cherts and local quartz. While early scholars dated the Eibian to the mid-Holocene due to superficial associations with pottery, recent excavations and radiocarbon dates from Gogoshiis Qabe and nearby sites (e.g., a 12,910 ± 180 BP ostrich eggshell date from Mirsaale) indicate a terminal Pleistocene age, firmly placing the Doian culture in a pre-ceramic Later Stone Age context. These findings make the Doian one of the earliest known microlithic industries in the Horn of Africa and a critical component in understanding the region's prehistoric humans.
